inlineContent.text: Actions can be used to expose functionality in a structured way, either
from one part of a program to another, or to the outside world. Action
groups are often used together with a [type
] that provides additional
representation data for displaying the actions to the user, e.g. in a menu.
The main way to interact with the actions in a
is to
activate them with [method
]. Activating an
action may require a [type[Variant](//documentation/glib/variant] parameter. The required type of the
parameter can be inquired with [method
Actions may be disabled, see [method
Activating a disabled action has no effect.
Actions may optionally have a state in the form of a [type[Variant](//documentation/glib/variant]. The current
state of an action can be inquired with [method
Activating a stateful action may change its state, but it is also possible to
set the state by calling [method
As typical example, consider a text editing application which has an
option to change the current font to ‘bold’. A good way to represent
this would be a stateful action, with a boolean state. Activating the
action would toggle the state.
Each action in the group has a unique name (which is a string).  All
method calls, except [method
] take the name of
an action as an argument.
The
API is meant to be the ‘public’ API to the action
group. The calls here are exactly the interaction that ‘external
forces’ (eg: UI, incoming D-Bus messages, etc.) are supposed to have
with actions. ‘Internal’ APIs (ie: ones meant only to be accessed by
the action group implementation) are found on subclasses. This is
why you will find – for example – [method
but not an equivalent
method.
Signals are emitted on the action group in response to state changes
on individual actions.
Implementations of
should provide implementations for
the virtual functions [method
] and
[method
]. The other virtual functions should
not be implemented — their ‘wrappers’ are actually implemented with
calls to [method
The
protocol exposes the methods and properties of an underlying
instance.
The default implementation of these can be found in the protocol extension below.
For a concrete class that implements these methods and properties, see
Alternatively, use
as a lighweight,
reference if you already have an instance you just want to use.

represents the contents of a menu — an ordered list of
menu items. The items are associated with actions, which can be
activated through them. Items can be grouped in sections, and may
have submenus associated with them. Both items and sections usually
have some representation data, such as labels or icons. The type of
the associated action (ie whether it is stateful, and what kind of
state it has) can influence the representation of the item.
